sections.subtitle: Execute Python Syntax
sections.text: As we learned in the previous page, Python syntax can be executed by writing directly in the Command Line. Or by creating a python file on the server, using the .py file extension, and running it in the Command Line

sections.subtitle: Python Indentation
sections.text:
Indentation refers to the spaces at the beginning of a code line.

Where in other programming languages the indentation in code is for 

readability only, the indentation in Python is very important. 

Python uses indentation to indicate a block of code.

sections.subtitle: Example
sections.text:
if 5 > 2:
    print("Five is greater than two!")
Python will give you an error if you skip the indentation:

sections.subtitle: Example
sections.text:
if 5 > 2:
print("Five is greater than two!")  # This will cause an error
The number of spaces is up to you as a programmer, the most common use is four, but it has to be at least one.

sections.subtitle: Example

sections.text: You have to use the same number of spaces in the same block of code, otherwise Python will give you an error
